title: High Street suffers worst September in eight years, report finds
text:
High street retailers endured the worst September in eight years, figures suggest, as shoppers rowed back on spending amid Brexit uncertainty and as another high-profile company collapsed.

Money spent in physical shops tumbled by 3.1 per cent in September, compared to the same period a year ago when sales also fell a bruising 2.7 per cent.

That makes it the poorest September since 2011, when the country was still recovering from the financial crisis.

Money spent in physical shops tumbled by 3.1% in September, according to BDO's High Street Sales Tracker

According to BDO's High Street Sales Tracker, a slowdown in discretionary spending led to a 5.4 per cent drop in sales in the lifestyle category - the worst performance for the sector since the height of the recession in 2008.

Fashion sales fell 2 per cent, marking the first decline for the category in three months.

BDO added that shopper numbers slumped throughout September, with a sharp 5.8 per cent drop a the end of the month when wet weather swept across the country.

But shopping centres experienced the worst of the downturn with footfall dropping 8 per cent in the final week.

An unwillingness to spend stretched to the internet too, BDO claimed, with online sales growth well below the yearly average at just 12.4 per cent.

Sophie Michael from BDO, said: 'As the Brexit date looms, the financial uncertainty facing consumers is reflected in the lack of discretionary spend and the lowest lifestyle sales since 2008.'

She added that shoppers were further 'unnerved' by the collapse of Thomas Cook - the world's oldest travel firm.

'It has been a disastrous year for the high street and, as consumers continue to tighten their belts, they are entering the crucial golden trading quarter on very unsteady ground,' Michael said.

High streets minister Jake Berry said: 'To support local retailers we've slashed business rates by a third, bringing the total amount of business rate support to over £13billion since 2016.'

'UK consumer confidence is coming into question,' said Joshua Mahony from IG.

The figures come the day after Ted Baker issued its third profit warning in seven months

The senior analyst argues that the current spending slowdown may endure until the likelihood of a no-deal Brexit is reduced.

'With a potential no-deal Brexit looming over markets, there is plenty of reasoning behind the notion that businesses and customers will remain somewhat restrained until we see some form of resolution to the current impasse,' he said.

The figures come the day after fashion chain Ted Baker issued its third profit warning in seven months, blaming consumer uncertainty, weak footfall and the weather.

The brand flagged that the wet weather in September took its toll on recent trading and warned that its second-half results would disappoint unless trading conditions improved.
